headline: Gabby Giffords' First 2 Words: 'What' and 'Chicken'
author: Newser Editors
sentences: "Imagine struggling to talk to your loved ones on the phone, the words you want to say on the tip of your tongue, but not being able to get them out," writes former Congresswoman Gabby Giffords, who survived a bullet wound to the brain 11 years ago, in the Washington Post.
"Or imagine struggling to talk to strangers: Though my cognition—my understanding and intelligence—is unaffected by my aphasia, sometimes that is not clear to new acquaintances because of my speech.
"My message for Bruce Willis and for everyone out there struggling with aphasia—or any other communication disorder—is that you are not alone," she writes.
The latter word would pop out frequently, as when she kept accidentally saying "happy birthday, chicken" to her husband, Sen. Mark Kelly.
Giffords recounts her slow recovery, including how the only two words she could say at first were "what" and, inexplicably, "chicken."
